We prove it in one direction: Let R be a reflexive, transitive and Euclidean relation. We need to show that R is an equivalence relation. Since R is already reflexive and transitive, it suffices to show that R is symmetric. To that end, assume that R(a, b). We have to show that R(b, a) holds as well. Since R is Euclidean, we have that R(x, y) and R(x, z) imply R(y, z) for all choices of x, y and z. So, if we instantiate this with x = a, y = b and z = a, then we have R(x, y) by assumption (as R(a, b)), but we also have R(x, z) since R is reflexive (so R(a, a) holds). Using that R in is Euclidean, we obtain R(y, z) which is R(b, a) as desired.
